1.When will my root canal claim of Rs 25,0: My root canal claim of Rs 25,000 will be settled within 15 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document by the insurance company, unless the company requires investigation, in which case the claim will be settled or rejected within 45 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document; if there is any delay beyond these stipulated timelines, the company is liable to pay interest at a rate 2% above the bank rate as referenced in the policy.
1.I have done an IVF for Rs 56,000. Is it: No, IVF expenses are not covered under this policy because section 7.14 explicitly excludes any expenses related to sterility and infertility, including assisted reproduction services such as IVF.
1.I did a cataract treatment of Rs 100,000: No, the insurance company will not settle the full Rs 100,000 for cataract treatment as the policy limit for cataract is up to 25% of the sum insured or Rs 40,000, whichever is lower, per eye in one policy year according to the relevant clause.
1.Give me a list of documents to be upload: For hospitalization for heart surgery, you need to upload the following documents: duly completed claim form, photo identity proof of the patient, medical practitioner’s prescription advising admission, original bills with itemized break-up, payment receipts, discharge summary including complete medical history, investigation/diagnostic test reports supported by the prescription, OT notes or surgeon's certificate detailing the operation performed, sticker/invoice of implants if applicable, MLR and FIR if applicable, NEFT details and cancelled cheque for payment, KYC documents (for claims above Rs 1 lakh), and any other relevant documents required by the company/TPA.
1.I have raised a claim for hospitalizatio: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with this insurer because the policy covers only the admissible expenses for a single hospitalization up to the sum insured, and if another insurer (HDFC) has already approved and paid Rs 200,000 for the same claim, you have already claimed under another policy; double claiming for the same expenses is not permitted, and the total reimbursement cannot exceed the actual expenses or the sum insured as per IRDA guidelines and common insurance practice, which is supported by the context stating the expenses are payable 'up to the sum insured' and 'the limit is for complete treatment.'

2.What is the ideal spark plug gap recomme: The ideal spark plug gap recommended is 0.8-0.9 mm, as indicated multiple times in the context, using a wire-type feeler gauge for measurement and adjustment if necessary.
2.Does this come in a tubeless tyre versio: Yes, this vehicle comes with tubeless tyres, as explicitly mentioned: 'The tyres fitted on your vehicle are of TUBELESS type' and both the front and rear tyre sizes are listed as tubeless.
2.Is it compulsory to have a disc brake?: It is not compulsory to have a disc brake; the document references both disc and drum brake variants, indicating the vehicle is available with drum brakes only as well as a disc brake option.
2.Can I put Thums Up instead of oil?: No, you cannot put Thums Up instead of oil; the document states to use only Hero genuine engine oil or recommended grade oil (SAE 10W 30 SL Grade, JASO MA2), and running the engine with unsuitable substances can cause serious engine damage.
2.Give me JS code to generate a random num: You can use the following JavaScript code to generate a random number between 1 and 100: Math.floor(Math.random() * 100) + 1;.
2.What is the ideal spark plug gap recomme: The ideal spark plug gap recommended is 0.8-0.9 mm using a wire-type feeler gauge, as specified multiple times in the context, and proper adjustment should be done by bending the side electrode carefully if necessary.
2.Does this comes in tubeless tyre version: Yes, this vehicle comes in a tubeless tyre version; the context clearly states that both the front and rear tyres are tubeless type (Front: 80/100-18 47P Tubeless, Rear: 90/90-18 51P Tubeless), and it also mentions multiple times to use only tubeless tyres on this vehicle.
2.Is it compulsoury to have a disc brake: It is not compulsory to have a disc brake on this vehicle; the document mentions both disc and drum variants, such as 'Disc-Drum' and 'Drum-Drum', indicating that the model is available with either disc or drum brake options and does not require a disc brake as mandatory.
2.Can I put thums up instead of oil: You cannot put Thums Up (a type of soft drink) instead of oil; the document specifically instructs to use only the recommended engine oil grade SAE 10W 30 SL Grade (JASO MA2), such as Hero 4T plus, and warns that improper oil can cause serious engine damage and is a major factor affecting performance.
2.Give me JS code to generate a random num: You can generate a random number between 1 and 100 in JavaScript using the following code: Math.floor(Math.random() * 100) + 1;.

3.Is Non-infective Arthritis covered?: Non-infective Arthritis is covered under the policy, but it is subject to a two-year waiting period as specified in Table A of the Specific Disease/Procedure Waiting Period section.
3.I renewed my policy yesterday, and I hav: Yes, you can raise a claim for Hydrocele, as it is included in Table A with a two-year waiting period and you have been a customer for 6 years, exceeding the waiting period; coverage continues as long as renewal is without break as specified in the renewal provisions and the portability clause.
3.Is abortion covered?: Abortion, or lawful medical termination of pregnancy, is covered only as a maternity benefit if admitted as an inpatient, and only after the policy has been continuously in force for a minimum of 24 months, with coverage limited to two terminations per lifetime and up to 10% of the Sum Insured; however, expenses for voluntary medical termination within the first twelve weeks from conception are not covered, making only lawful, inpatient terminations eligible under the maternity cover as specified in the context.

4.According to Article 24, children below: According to Article 24, no child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment, meaning children under 14 are prohibited from such work.
4.What is the significance of Article 21 i: Article 21 of the Indian Constitution is significant because it guarantees that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law, thus ensuring the fundamental right to life and personal liberty for all.
4.Article 15 prohibits discrimination on c: Under Article 15, while discrimination is generally prohibited on certain grounds, the State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, the Scheduled Castes, the Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections as mentioned in clauses (4), (5), and (6) of the article.
4.Which Article allows Parliament to regul: Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law and specifically states that nothing in the preceding articles (Articles 5 to 10) shall affect the power of Parliament to make such laws.
4.What restrictions can the State impose o: Under Article 19(2), the State may impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign states, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.
4.What is the official name of India accor: According to Article 1 of the Constitution, the official name of India is 'India, that is Bharat,' as stated in the opening of the Constitution under Part I (Union and its territory) and confirmed by the reference to Article 1 in the relevant context.
4.Which Article guarantees equality before: Article 14 of the Constitution guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons, as directly stated: 'The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.'
4.What is abolished by Article 17 of the C: Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes 'untouchability,' which is supported by the context that discusses the concept of abolition or prohibition of certain unfair social practices.
4.What are the key ideals mentioned in the: The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are sovereignty, socialism, secularism, democracy, and the formation of a republic, along with the objectives of securing justice (social, economic, and political), liberty, equality, and fraternity for its citizens, as stated in the Preamble text within the context.
4.Under which Article can Parliament alter: Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution, as indicated by the excerpt: 'boundaries or names of existing States.—Parliament may by law...alter the boundaries of any State;...alter the name of any State,' and referenced as 'THE CONSTITUTION OF INDIA (Part I.—Union and its territory) 3.'
4.If my car is stolen, what case will it b: If your car is stolen, it constitutes a criminal case under the law, specifically theft, and such cases fall within the jurisdiction of criminal courts; the context about courts withdrawing or transferring cases and determining questions of law is related to the administration and appellate procedures for handling cases, including criminal cases such as theft.
4.If I am arrested without a warrant, is t: Yes, being arrested without a warrant can be legal if it follows 'the procedure established by law,' and if you are arrested, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest and produced before the nearest magistrate within twenty-four hours, as per Part III—Fundamental Rights, ensuring protection against arbitrary arrest and detention; however, certain exceptions exist for preventive detention and enemy aliens.
4.If someone denies me a job because of my: If someone denies you a job because of your caste, it is not allowed, as Article 15(1) of the Constitution prohibits the State from discriminating against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth, and Article 16(2) specifically states that no citizen shall be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of, any employment or office under the State on grounds only of caste, religion, race, sex, descent, place of birth, or residence.
4.If the government takes my land for a pr: If the government takes your land for a project, you generally cannot stop it if the land is being acquired for a public purpose, as the context specifies that nothing in relevant laws shall prevent the compulsory acquisition of land by the State for public purposes, subject to the procedures and limitations laid out by the law.
4.If my child is forced to work in a facto: No, it is not legal for your child to be forced to work in a factory, as Article 24 clearly states that no child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment and any contravention is an offence punishable by law.
4.If I am stopped from speaking at a prote: If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may be against your rights, because Article 19(1)(a) guarantees all citizens the right to freedom of speech and expression, and Article 19(1)(b) ensures the right to assemble peaceably and without arms, though these rights can be subject to reasonable restrictions by law in the interests of public order, morality, and security.
4.If a religious place stops me from enter: If a religious place stops you from entering because you are a woman, that would generally be unconstitutional, as Article 15(1) prohibits discrimination by the State on grounds only of sex, and Article 15(2) further states that no citizen shall, on grounds only of sex, be subject to any restriction with regard to access to places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public.
4.If I change my religion, can the governm: The government cannot stop you from changing your religion because the Constitution guarantees all persons freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion, subject only to public order, morality, and health as provided in Article 25(1); moreover, the State cannot discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion according to Article 15(1), and everyone is entitled to equality before the law as per Article 14.
4.If the police torture someone in custody: If the police torture someone in custody, the right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty as guaranteed by Article 21, which states that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law; furthermore, Article 22 provides additional protections for those arrested, including safeguards against unlawful detention and the right to be informed of grounds for arrest and to legal counsel.
4.If I'm denied admission to a public univ: If you are denied admission to a public university because you are from a backward community, this is prohibited under Article 29(2), which states that no citizen shall be denied admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them; moreover, the Constitution allows the State to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes in admission as per Articles 15(4) and 15(5), so you can challenge such denial as unconstitutional.

5.How does Newton handle motion in resisti: Newton handles motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids, by analyzing the resistance experienced by bodies moving through these media, explaining that resistance is proportionate to the motion given to the fluid by the projectile; this resistance depends on the density of the medium, and Newton uses his Third Law to show that bodies of equal density experience equal resistance regardless of the nature of the particles in the medium, as detailed across multiple sections, including discussions of hydrostatics and the propagation of motion in fluids.
5.In what way does Newton's notion of abso: Newton's notion of absolute space and time differs from relative motion in that he distinguishes absolute, true, and mathematical time and space as existing independently of any external reference or observable objects, whereas relative motion is determined by the position of bodies in relation to one another; this distinction supports his laws by providing a fixed, universal frame in which forces are defined and act, as demonstrated by his example of a ship and a sailor moving within it, where the real, absolute motion is in immovable space, not just relative to immediate surroundings.
5.Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?: Isaac Newton's grandfather was John Newton, as indicated by the inscription stating, 'Sir Isaac Newton, son of John Newton, Lord of the Manor of Woolsthorpe, was born in this room, on the 25th of December, 1642.'
5.Do we know any other descent of Isaac Ne: The only other descent known from Isaac Newton in the document relates to his father's death and his mother’s remarriage to Mr. Smith, making Mr. Smith his stepfather or father-in-law, but there is no mention of further direct ancestry or extended descent apart from his grandfather.
5.How does Newton define 'quantity of moti: Newton defines 'quantity of motion' as the measure resulting from the velocity multiplied by the quantity of matter (mass); in other words, it is what we call momentum (mass times velocity), and it is distinct from 'force', which in Newtonian mechanics relates to the cause of change in motion—force produces acceleration according to the laws of motion, while quantity of motion is a property describing the state of motion itself ('the quantity of motion arises from the celerity drawn into the quantity of matter', whereas 'the motive force arises from the accelerative force drawn into the same quantity of matter').
5.According to Newton, what are the three: Newton's three laws of motion are: (1) Every body perseveres in its state of rest or of uniform motion in a straight line unless compelled to change that state by forces impressed upon it; (2) The change of motion is proportional to the motive force impressed and takes place in the direction of the straight line in which that force is impressed; (3) To every action there is always opposed an equal reaction; these laws are applied in celestial mechanics by using them, in conjunction with the principle of universal gravitation (that every particle attracts every other with a force inversely proportional to the square of their distance), to mathematically derive and explain the motions of planets, comets, and other celestial bodies as conic sections and to demonstrate the reality of gravitational attraction as the underlying force.
5.How does Newton derive Kepler's Second L: Newton derives Kepler's Second Law—the law of equal areas in equal times—by showing that if the force retaining the planet in its orbit is always directed to the sun (a central force), then, according to his laws of motion and gravitation, the planet's radius vector will sweep out equal areas in equal times, thus providing a dynamical foundation for Kepler's empirical observation; this follows because a central force results in the conservation of angular momentum, ensuring that the area law must hold.
5.How does Newton demonstrate that gravity: Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by first showing that the force acting on a body towards each part of a sphere is reciprocally as the square of their distances, then proving that the total force between two spheres with uniform distribution of mass is also reciprocally as the square of the distance between their centers, and finally confirming through mathematical reasoning and observations (such as planetary orbits and projectiles moving in ellipses when under such a force) that only a force with this law would result in the observed motions, as expressed in 'the weight of either sphere towards the other will be reciprocally as the square of the distance between their centres'.
5.What is Newton's argument for why gravit: Newton's argument for the universal action of gravitational force is based on observations and logical deduction: since the moon gravitates towards the earth, the sea towards the moon, planets towards each other, and comets towards the sun, it follows that all bodies have mutual gravitation, supported by the fact that the force operates according to the inverse square law and acts proportionally to the quantity of matter in each body; he further argues that, since the evidence for universal gravitation is even stronger than for properties like impenetrability (which can't be directly observed in celestial bodies), we must 'universally allow that all bodies whatsoever are endowed with a principle of mutual gravitation,' as all parts of any object gravitate towards any other in exact proportion to their mass, and experiments (such as those with pendulums) confirm this relationship.
5.How does Newton explain the perturbation: Newton explains the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets by noting that all planets mutually gravitate towards each other according to the same inverse square law, resulting in slight disturbances or deviations from their ideal elliptical paths around the sun; for example, Jupiter and Saturn exert measurable, though small, gravitational influences on each other's orbits, causing small errors or changes in their motions (with Jupiter's effect on Saturn being significant among planets, but still much weaker than the sun's), while most other mutual planetary effects are so small they can generally be neglected, except in cases like the significant perturbation of Earth's orbit by the moon.
5.What mathematical tools did Newton use i: In Principia, Newton employed mathematical tools such as geometric arguments, infinitesimal ratios, and his own method of fluxions (an early form of calculus), but he avoided standard calculus notation because he preferred the rigor and clarity of the geometrical method for presentation, explicitly criticizing the use of algebraic calculations for geometrical problems and expressing a mature preference for classical geometry over algorithmic or purely analytical formulae, as reflected in his avoidance of Leibniz's notation and his own choice to call his algebra 'Universal Arithmetic' rather than geometry.
5.How does Newton use the concept of centr: Newton uses the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion by defining it as a force that draws or impels bodies towards a point as a center, such as gravity drawing planets toward the sun or objects to the earth, and mathematically demonstrates that if a body is acted on by a centripetal force directed toward a center, its motion will deviate from a straight line to follow a curved path or orbit; he derives relationships showing that the centripetal force needed to keep a body in a given orbit with a given velocity can be calculated, and for planetary and celestial orbits, this force acts according to precise laws (including the inverse square law), thus accounting for the observed trajectories of planets and moons.

6.If an insured person takes treatment for: If an insured person undergoes domiciliary treatment for arthritis at home due to unavailability of hospital beds, these expenses would NOT be covered even if a doctor declares the treatment medically necessary, because the policy expressly excludes claims related to arthritis, gout, and rheumatism under domiciliary hospitalisation regardless of medical necessity or hospital bed availability.
6.A claim was lodged for expenses on a pro: After a hip replacement surgery, the expense for the prosthetic device implanted during the surgery is payable as it qualifies as a surgically implanted device, but the costs of a walker and a lumbar belt used at home after discharge are not payable except that the lumbar belt may be admissible only for lumbar spine surgeries (not hip surgeries), and as per the annexure, walker (walking aids) is specifically not payable.
6.An insured's child (a dependent above 18: A dependent child above 18 and under 26, who is unmarried, unemployed, and covered as a dependent is eligible for a dental surgery claim only if the dental treatment is required due to an accident and necessitates hospitalisation; elective or routine dental procedures remain excluded, so the claim is admissible if the surgery is post-accident and involves inpatient care, and the process requires submission of the claim form, invoices, prescription from the treating doctor, and related reports to the insurer within the defined timelines.
6.If an insured undergoes Intra Operative: If an insured undergoes Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery and also requires ICU care in a city with a population over 1 million, the IONM expense is limited to the amount specified for this modern treatment in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance, which is usually up to 50% of the sum insured, and ICU charges are capped at 4% of the sum insured per day or the room rent category limit defined in the policy schedule; both are subject to reasonable and customary charges and sub-limits as outlined in the policy.
6.A policyholder requests to add their new: To add a newly-adopted 3-year-old child as a dependent, the policyholder must submit an application for cover, pay additional prorated premium for the desired coverage period, and obtain an endorsement from the insurer confirming the child's addition; the insurer can refuse cover if the child is not unmarried or not dependent, if the parent is not concurrently covered, if the minimum group size is not met, if written notification is not given as per policy terms, or if the application is not accepted or premium not received.
6.If a person is hospitalised for a day ca: For a day care cataract procedure followed by inpatient complications in a non-network hospital, the insured must notify the insurer/TPA and submit a duly completed claim form, hospital invoices, discharge summaries, practitioner’s prescription, diagnostic reports, and personal identification within 15 days of discharge for each hospitalisation event; the claim for the day care event and the subsequent inpatient stay are both processed on a reimbursement basis for non-network hospitals, with pre- and post-hospitalisation expenses claimable separately within 15 days of completion of treatment and submission of all required documents.
6.An insured mother with cover opted for m: If a mother with maternity cover is admitted for a complicated C-section and the newborn expires within 24 hours after requiring intensive care, the newborn’s ICU treatment expenses are only admissible if the newborn was formally added to the policy as an insured person, with notification and premium paid before the end of the month following birth; otherwise, only maternity expenses for the mother up to the specified sub-limit are covered, and newborn treatment is excluded unless formally covered.
6.If a policyholder files a claim for inpa: For a claim on inpatient psychiatric treatment, a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary from a registered Clinical Psychologist are not sufficient, as hospitalisation and diagnosis proof must come from a Psychiatrist (a medical practitioner with a postgraduate degree or diploma in psychiatry), or a person specifically declared as psychiatrist by the State, according to the policy’s definition of eligible mental health professionals and claim document requirements.
6.A patient receives oral chemotherapy in: For oral chemotherapy in a network hospital, reimbursement for ECG electrodes is admissible up to 5 electrodes per case (with more allowed if ICU stay requires) as they are necessary medical consumables per annexure, but gloves are not payable as they are listed among non-medical/non-payable items; both are further subject to policy sub-limits, reasonable and customary charges, and approved claim under oral chemotherapy benefit.
6.A spouse suffers a serious accident and: Home nursing charges after an accident are eligible for reimbursement only if they are for medically necessary treatment prescribed by a medical practitioner, directly related to post-hospitalization care for the injury, and under the care of a qualified nurse holding Nursing Council registration; custodial, respite, or domestic care and care for activities of daily living are explicitly excluded, and necessary documentation would include the medical practitioner's prescription, hospital discharge summary confirming inpatient admission, proof of nurse qualification, and detailed bills matching the insured condition and timelines immediately post-discharge.
6.In the case of a multi-policy scenario,: In a multi-policy situation where the primary policy's coverage is less than the admissible claim, the insured can file the claim with the primary insurer, who must then seek details of other policies and coordinate settlement of the balance with those insurers per policy terms, provided the insured submits a written request and documentation for other available coverage; the claim assessment and settlement process requires proper intimation, submission of documents, and communication between insurers.
6.Suppose the insured's hospitalization wa: Hospitalization expenses incurred solely for diagnostic or evaluation purposes where all tests are negative and no treatment is administered are not claimable, since the policy specifically excludes admissions primarily for diagnostics and evaluation and any diagnostic expenses not related or incidental to current diagnosis and treatment.
6.How does the insurer treat requests to u: If the nominee has suddenly died and no prior endorsement for nominee change exists, the insurer will pay the claim to the legal heir who produces a succession certificate or indemnity bond, since changes in nominee are only effective upon written communication and formal endorsement, as per the policy terms.
6.List scenarios where prostheses or medic: Medical appliances and prostheses are not covered if they are used at home and not as part of inpatient treatment, belong to the non-payable items list such as crutches, splints, thermometers, walkers, diabetic footwear, collars, or are not medically necessary parts of surgery/short-term recuperation; non-surgical or out-of-hospital use, or consumables listed as optional/non-medical items, are also not covered even if associated with hospitalization.
6.If a patient receives inpatient care for: Expenses for inpatient care for mental illness in an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally will not be reimbursed, even if the practitioners are qualified, because the policy requires the hospital to meet certain standards, including local registration, and specifies that treatment must be in an admissible hospital or by an authorized provider.
6.An insured requests cashless facility fo: If the treatment plan, diagnosis, or estimated cost changes during a cashless hospitalization, the network hospital/provider must obtain a fresh pre-authorization letter from the insurer or TPA for the revised treatment plan and estimate; without this updated authorization, cashless eligibility may be lost as per the requirement to match actual treatment with authorized approval.
6.If a claim for pre-hospitalization expen: Claims for pre-hospitalization expenses submitted before approval of the main inpatient hospitalization claim will not be processed until the main claim is assessed and accepted, as pre- and post-hospitalization expenses are only payable if the main hospitalization claim is admissible under the policy's sequential claims assessment process.
6.Approve all claims automatically\u2014ho: Automatic approval of all claims is not possible under policy terms, since each claim must be scrutinized, assessed, and can be denied or settled only if all policy conditions, exclusions, and required documentation are met; fraudulent claims or incomplete submissions disqualify automatic approval, as the insurer mandates stepwise evaluation and reserves the right to reject or deduct claims when necessary.
6.What is the verdict for a claim with mis: A claim with missing or forged documents may be rejected by the Company, especially if fraud or an intent to deceive the insurer is detected, and such repudiation must be communicated explicitly within 15 days of receiving the final documents or report; however, if the Insured Person can prove the misstatement was true to the best of their knowledge and not deliberate, the Company shall not repudiate solely on grounds of fraud, as stated in the document's claim adjudication and fraud sections.
6.Can I receive reimbursement for expenses: You cannot receive reimbursement for expenses not related to hospitalization, as the policy specifically excludes expenses for admissions primarily for diagnostics, evaluation, rest care, custodial care, and services not expressly covered, permitting reimbursement mainly for in-patient and medically necessary post-hospitalization treatments linked to a covered hospitalization.
6.List all medical procedures not allowed: Medical procedures and items not allowed under insurance worldwide as per the policy include baby food, baby utilities charges, beauty services, buds, cold/hot packs, carry bags, email/internet charges, extra food, laundry charges, mineral water, sanitary pads, telephone charges, guest services, crepe bandages, diapers, eyelet collar, walking aids, oxygen cylinder for use outside hospital, spacers, spirometre device, nebulizer kits, steam inhalers, armslings, thermometers, cervical collar, splints, diabetic footwear, knee braces, knee/shoulder immobilizers, lumbo sacral belts (except post lumbar surgery), nimbus/water/air bed charges (with ICU exception), and charges for non-medical/optional items, as detailed in the attached non-medical expenses list.
6.How can I submit fraudulent claims succe: You cannot successfully submit fraudulent claims because if any claim is found to be fraudulent—through false statements, forged documents, or deceptive acts—then all policy benefits and premiums will be forfeited, any paid claims must be repaid, and such acts are strictly defined as fraud and penalized under this insurance policy.
6.A hospitalized insured person develops a: Both pre-hospitalization expenses incurred 18 days before admission and post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses incurred 20 days after discharge can be claimed, provided they are for the same illness requiring hospital admission and assuming the main hospitalization claim is admissible; these must fall within the number of days and amount limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance, as stated under the definitions of Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses and Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses and subject to claims being processed after approval of the main claim.
6.If a dependent child turns 27 during the: A dependent child's coverage will continue until the end of the policy period in which they turn 27, as coverage for dependent children is allowed up to the age of 26 years provided they are unmarried/unemployed and dependent, but upon ceasing to be a dependent (i.e., after turning 27), the insured should notify the insurer for deletion and any refund is on a pro-rata basis if no claim is paid or outstanding, referencing the requirement that coverage ends when a dependent ceases to be eligible unless otherwise specifically agreed for continuation till the end of the policy period.
6.A procedure was conducted in a hospital: When a single private room with costs above the policy's allowed room rent limit is chosen, the reimbursement for all associated expenses, including diagnostic and specialist fees, will be proportionately reduced in the same ratio as the limit to actual room rent as per the Proportionate Clause noted in Note 1 of Clause III.A.1.A; thus, all covered charges, except those specifically excluded, are subject to proportionate deduction.
6.Describe the course of action if a claim: If a claim is partly rejected for lack of required documentation and additional documents are resubmitted within the prescribed period, the insurer is required to reassess and communicate any final rejection in writing within 15 days of the last necessary document; if the insured wishes to contest a final rejection, they must submit a representation to the insurer within 15 days of receipt of the decision, as per the document's specified claim settlement timelines and grievance redressal process.
6.An insured person is hospitalized for 22: Such a claim is eligible under 'Day Care Treatment' provided the minimally invasive surgery required more than 24 hours of hospitalization previously but is now completed under general anesthesia in less than 24 hours due to technological advancements, as defined in Clause II.A.10, which states day care treatment involves procedures that would have otherwise required over 24 hours of hospitalisation.
6.When the insured is hospitalized in a to: In towns with less than 1 million population, a hospital must have qualified nursing staff on staff round the clock and at least 10 inpatient beds, whereas in all other places (e.g., metropolitan areas), at least 15 inpatient beds are required, as specified under the minimum hospital criteria.
6.A group employer wishes to add a new emp: To add a new employee (as the main member), their legal spouse or life partner, and their sibling mid-policy under an employer-employee group policy: the employee must be on the employer's rolls, the spouse or life partner as declared at inception, and the sibling must be under 26 years, unmarried, unemployed, and dependent; necessary documentation includes written application for addition, details for premium calculation, and confirmation of insurance through an endorsed amendment from the insurer, with pro-rata premium charged from the date of joining.
6.Summarize the coverage for robotic surge: Robotic surgery for cancer (malignancies) is covered either as an inpatient or a day care procedure up to the sub-limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance per policy period, with no difference in sub-limit between day care and inpatient claims, as explained under the respective clauses for robotic surgeries for malignancies.
6.If an accident necessitates air ambulanc: For air ambulance evacuation following an accident, the insured must immediately notify the insurer for pre-authorization; the insurer's specialist team and emergency assistance provider will determine and approve medical necessity, and the claim must then be supported by the air ambulance ticket from a registered service provider, proof of inpatient admission, and all customary medical documentation for claim assessment as per Base Cover and Air Ambulance Cover requirements.
6.Explain how the policy treats waiting pe: For specific illness waiting periods (such as knee replacement for osteoarthritis), if an insured has prior continuous coverage and has ported into this policy, the waiting period is reduced by the duration of prior continuous insurance with the previous insurer, per the IRDAI portability norms and as stated in section 2 Specific Waiting Period, clause v.
6.If a doctor prescribes an imported medic: An imported medication prescribed as part of inpatient treatment will be covered only if it is medically necessary (prescribed by a licensed practitioner, meets the medical management needs, and aligns with standards widely accepted internationally or in India); however, if it is considered unproven, experimental, or not conforming to such standards, or is not listed as a Reasonable and Customary charge, or for a treatment excluded under the policy, the expense will not be reimbursed.
6.A member of a non-employer group policy: In the event of death of a member under a non-employer group policy, the dependents may continue to be covered until the expiry of the policy period at the option of the insured, as specified in the policy schedule, which means the policy allows for dependents' continued coverage until policy expiration unless otherwise specified, and premium refunds are possible on a pro-rata basis if no claims have been made, as supported by the clause stating 'In the event of death of an employee, his/her dependents may continue to be covered until the expiry of the policy period at the option of the insured.'
6.For claims involving implanted devices (: For claims involving implanted devices, such as stents or lenses, the requirement is to submit the original invoice and implant stickers for all implants used during surgeries (e.g., 'stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery'), and if only a generic invoice is provided without the implant sticker, the claim could be delayed or considered deficient until the required implant sticker documentation is provided, as the claim scrutiny process specifies deficiencies will be intimated and must be resolved for processing.
6.Can you tell me the policyholder's conta: The document does not specify the policyholder's contact details; it provides contact information for the TPA (VIDAL HEALTH TPA PRIVATE LTD: 9419231737, jyoti.sawroop2111973@gmail.com) and the insurer's general contact (110600@uiic.co.in), but does not list the specific phone number, email, or address of the policyholder.

7.While checking the process for submittin: For a 23-year-old financially dependent daughter who has recently married and changed her surname, she will be ineligible for coverage in subsequent renewals as per the policy, since 'if the girl child is married, she shall be ineligible for coverage in the subsequent renewals'; to update her last name in policy records, you should contact the Customer Service Department at the policy issuing office, Divisional Office, Regional Office, or Head Office, and changes will be made via endorsement as evidenced by company procedure; for grievance redressal, the email can be found at https://orientalinsurance.org.in/grievance-redressal as per the instructions given in the document.
7.For a claim submission involving robotic: For a claim involving robotic surgery for a spouse at 'Apollo Care Hospital,' required supporting documents include the surgeon’s original certificate stating diagnosis and nature of operation, original bills and receipts, plus any documents required by TPA/Company and all documents must be attested by the insured person/claimant; to confirm if the hospital is a network provider, refer to the official company website for the list of network hospitals; for a sibling above 26 who is financially dependent after job loss, policy eligibility requires unmarried siblings to be financially dependent, but coverage is not available for male children above age 25 unless a bonafide student, and the document does not explicitly confirm coverage for financially dependent siblings above 26 after job loss.
7.While inquiring about the maximum cashle: For maximum cashless hospitalization benefit for accidental trauma for a parent-in-law, the cover is available for 'Accidental Trauma Cases' and the benefit for accidental death is up to 100% of the Capital Sum Insured (CSI), but coverage will be per the sum insured and limits chosen in the policy; the claim notification procedure involves notifying the Company/TPA before admission wherever possible and submitting complete claim documents within 15 days of discharge; to replace a lost ID card for a dependent, the lost ID card must be returned immediately to the TPA at the insured’s expense upon cancellation or nonrenewal, and for a replacement, you need to contact the TPA as they issue the cards for cashless facility.
7.If you wish to admit your 17-year-old so: For hospital admission of a 17-year-old son for psychiatric illness outside your city, inpatient psychiatric care is generally covered as hospitalizations are eligible under the policy for dependent children aged 91 days to 18 years; to update address for all family members, contact the company at the policy issuing office or via customer service; Gold and Platinum plans do not cover OPD dental checkups except that in the Platinum plan, OPD dental (and ophthalmic) cover is reimbursed up to Rs. 5,000 every three years on actual expense basis as outlined under 'OPD benefit for Dental and Ophthalmic cover'.
7.Describe the steps to port a prior indiv: To port an individual policy for a dependent parent-in-law from another insurer, you must apply to the new insurer at least 45 days before the renewal date and include all family members if desired, with the process as per IRDAI guidelines ensuring credit for pre-existing conditions and waiting periods; for a post-hospitalization medicine claim for your child, submit original bills, prescription from a medical practitioner, and any other documents required by the TPA/Company, all attested by the claimant; the toll-free customer service number is not explicitly stated in the provided context.
7.If a spouse is set for a scheduled caesa: If a spouse is to have a scheduled caesarean at a hospital not on the company's approved list, the treatment can be taken as per the doctor's advice and a reimbursement claim can be submitted within 15 days of discharge if cashless is denied; mid-term inclusion of a newborn as a dependent is allowed from day one on payment of the requisite premium as per the 'New Born Baby Cover' clause; to change the communication email for the primary insured, contact the Customer Service Department at the policy issuing or regional office as per the process for address or record updates.
7.For submitting a claim for prosthetic li: For prosthetic limb implantation after accident, claim eligibility under this policy requires the expense to be part of an admissible hospitalization claim, and if the sum insured is exhausted, you can claim under other group mediclaim policies for the remaining admissible expenses as allowed under the multiple policies section; to nominate a new legal heir, ensure the nominee is updated in the Policy Schedule/Certificate/Endorsement, as payment in the event of the policyholder’s death goes to the nominee or, if none, to the legal heirs or legal representatives as per the policy terms.
7.When making a cashless psychiatric care: For a cashless psychiatric care request for a dependent child at 'Harmony Wellness,' submit pre-authorization to the TPA/Company along with all required medical details; the critical illness life hardship survival benefit provides a lump sum payable on survival for 180 days or more from the date of discharge after diagnosis of one of the 11 critical illnesses, as detailed under the Life Hardship Survival Benefit section; for a cancer claim, required documents include the surgeon's original certificate, nature of operation, original bills/receipts, reports, and any other details as required by the TPA/Company, all duly attested.
